requirements.target_audience: Hobbyists, robotics enthusiasts, and drone developers
requirements.core_function: A self-navigating quadcopter drone capable of autonomous flight, GPS waypoint navigation, obstacle avoidance, and return-to-home functionality
components_needed: u-blox NEO-M8N GPS module with antenna
HC-SR04 ultrasonic distance sensors x4 (obstacle avoidance)
Matek PDB (power distribution board) with 5V/12V BEC
MicroSD card module (SPI) for flight logging
Schottky diode SS34 x4 (reverse polarity protection)
M3 nylon standoffs and screws kit
Vibration damping mount/gimbal for flight controller
safety_requirements: Low battery voltage alarm and auto-land
Reverse polarity protection on power input
LED status indicators for arming state
requirements.special_notes: Requires PID tuning for stable autonomous flight. Firmware can be based on ArduPilot, Betaflight, or custom STM32 firmware. GPS waypoint navigation requires open-sky conditions for accurate positioning. Obstacle avoidance is basic (ultrasonic, 4 directions) and not suitable for dense environments. Flight time estimated at 15-25 minutes depending on payload and conditions. Compliance with local drone regulations (FAA Part 107 in US) is required. Ground control station can be implemented via MAVLink protocol over ESP32 Wi-Fi to a laptop or smartphone app.

bom.name: STM32F405RGT6-STMICROELECTRONICS-ARM MCU, Advanced Connectivity and Encryption, STM32 Family STM32F4 Series Microcontrollers (Arm Microcontrollers Ic)

power_rails.name: VBAT (14.8V 4S LiPo)
power_rails.source: 4S 14.8V 5200mAh LiPo via XT60 connector through SS34 Schottky diode (reverse polarity protection)

power_rails.name: 5V_BEC
power_rails.source: Matek PDB 5V BEC output (primary) + MP1584EN 5V 3A buck converter (secondary/redundant from VBAT)

power_rails.name: 12V_BEC
consumers: Optional peripherals, FPV camera future expansion

power_rails.name: 3.3V_TELEM
consumers: ESP32-WROOM-32E (dedicated due to high current draw ~500mA peaks)

power_rails.name: ESC_POWER
power_rails.source: Matek PDB direct VBAT pads (4 outputs to 4 ESCs)

connections.notes: Via 10K pull-down to GND, 1K series gate resistor. HIGH = power ON to ESCs
100nF ceramic cap on EACH VDD pin to GND
1uF + 100nF decoupling, ferrite bead from 3.3V_MCU for analog supply isolation
100nF decoupling; could use CR2032 for RTC backup
Via 10K pull-up + 100nF to GND for noise filtering
Via 10K pull-down; jumper to 3.3V for DFU bootloader mode
8MHz HSE crystal, 20pF load caps to GND on each side
Optional LSE for RTC, 6.8pF load caps
Data-ready interrupt, active low, 10K pull-up to 3.3V
Frame sync not used, tie low
Shared I2C1 bus, pull-ups already on bus
Pull HIGH to select I2C mode (not SPI)
4.7K pull-up to 3.3V_MCU. Separate I2C2 bus to isolate from vibration-sensitive IMU bus
1PPS timing pulse for precise time sync, capture via timer input
Via SMA connector or direct solder, keep antenna clear of interference sources
100nF + 10uF decoupling. ESP32 peaks ~500mA during Wi-Fi TX
MAVLink telemetry TX, 115200 baud. Using PC10 for USART3_TX
10K pull-up, 100nF to GND for delayed enable
10K pull-up for normal boot; pull LOW for flashing
Keep ground plane clearance under ESP32 antenna area

component_placement.notes: Central placement for shortest trace runs to all peripherals. 100nF decoupling caps on EACH VDD pin placed within 2mm. Ferrite bead + 1uF+100nF on VDDA. Ground pad soldered to inner ground plane via multiple vias.
Place within 5mm of STM32 PH0/PH1 pins. 20pF load caps directly at crystal pads. Guard ring ground trace around crystal. Keep copper pour away from crystal traces.
Near PC14/PC15 pins. 6.8pF load caps. Optional for RTC.

CRITICAL: Place at exact geometric center of board for best vibration characteristics. Align axes with board edges. Keep away from motors, high-current traces, and magnetic components. 100nF decoupling cap within 1mm. Ground plane solid underneath with no splits.
Place near MPU6050 on shared I2C1 bus. Cover with light-blocking foam in assembly. Keep away from airflow and heat sources. 100nF decoupling.

component_placement.position: board edge, away from power traces
component_placement.notes: CRITICAL: Place as far as possible from high-current power traces, ESC connections, motors, and ferrous components. Bottom-left corner away from power input. No copper pour within 5mm except dedicated ground. Orient consistently with board axes. 100nF decoupling.
Place at board edge for downward-facing mounting. I2C2 separate bus from IMU. JST-PH connector for external module wiring option. 100nF decoupling.

CRITICAL: Antenna portion MUST overhang board edge or have NO ground plane/copper within 15mm of antenna area on ALL layers. Place at top edge. 10uF + 100nF decoupling. 10K pull-ups on EN and GPIO0. 10K pull-down on GPIO2. Keep RF traces short.
JST-PH or pin header connector for external GPS module. GPS module mounted externally on mast above frame to minimize interference. Route UART2 traces (PA2/PA3) with ground guard. PPS line to PA15.
For external GPS antenna. 50-ohm impedance-controlled trace if routing RF on PCB.
Optional external antenna for ESP32 if using U.FL variant.
Powers STM32, MPU6050, BMP280, MMC5603, SD card, VL53L0X. 10uF + 100nF on input AND output. Thermal pad to ground plane. Keep input/output caps within 3mm.
Dedicated for ESP32 (~500mA peaks) and GPS (~70mA). Isolated from MCU rail to prevent Wi-Fi TX noise from affecting sensors. 10uF + 100nF on input AND output. Thermal pad to ground plane.
Redundant 5V BEC from VBAT. Place in power section away from sensitive analog/IMU area. Module connects via pin headers.
Pin header or solder pads for connection to external Matek PDB. VBAT+, GND, 5V_BEC, 12V_BEC lines. Heavy gauge pads for high current.
Inline with VBAT+ from XT60. Handles full battery current. Adequate copper pour for heat dissipation.
Master ESC power switch. Gate driven from STM32 PA0 via 1K series resistor, 10K pull-down to GND. Drain from D1 cathode, Source to PDB VBAT+. Thermal relief to ground plane.
Solder pads for XT60 pigtail wiring. 14AWG capable copper pads. Wide traces (3mm+) to D1.
JST-PH or 3-pin header. SBUS signal to STM32 PA10 (USART1_RX). 5V_BEC power. Inverted SBUS signal needs hardware inverter (1K + 1K voltage divider or transistor inverter) before STM32.
4x 3-pin headers (Signal, 5V, GND) for ESC PWM/DShot connections. ESC1=PA6(TIM3_CH1), ESC2=PA7(TIM3_CH2), ESC3=PB0(TIM3_CH3), ESC4=PB1(TIM3_CH4). Group together for clean wiring.

4x 4-pin JST-PH headers at board edges: Front(top), Back(bottom), Left, Right. Trig/Echo pairs: Front=PC6/PC7, Right=PC8/PC9, Back=PA8/PA9(alt), Left=PB14/PB15. 5V power, 1K+2K voltage divider on Echo pins (5V->3.3V level shift).
SPI1 interface: PA5(SCK), PA6_ALT/PB5(MOSI), PB4(MISO), PA4(CS). JST-PH or pin header for external SD module. Keep SPI traces short and matched length.
Driven via NPN transistor/MOSFET from STM32 PB9. 5V_BEC power. Place at board edge for audibility.
Single data pin from STM32 PB8 (TIM4_CH3 for DMA). 5V power. 470 ohm series resistor on data line. 100nF + 470uF bulk cap at connector for LED power.

tools_required.name: Soldering iron
tools_required.notes: Temperature-controlled, 350°C recommended. A fine-tip chisel or conical tip for SMD/through-hole work

tools_required.name: Solder wire
tools_required.notes: 60/40 or 63/37 tin-lead, 0.8mm diameter. Lead-free alternative: SAC305

tools_required.name: Soldering flux
tools_required.notes: Rosin-based no-clean flux pen or paste for clean joints

tools_required.name: Desoldering pump or wick
tools_required.notes: For correcting solder mistakes

tools_required.name: Third-hand/helping hands tool
tools_required.notes: With alligator clips and magnifying glass for holding PCBs

tools_required.name: Digital multimeter
tools_required.notes: Must measure voltage, current, resistance, and continuity

tools_required.name: Wire strippers
tools_required.notes: Capable of stripping 14AWG to 22AWG wire

tools_required.name: Wire cutters/flush cutters
tools_required.notes: For trimming leads and cutting wire

tools_required.name: Needle-nose pliers
tools_required.notes: For bending leads, holding small parts

tools_required.name: Hex driver set (metric)
tools_required.notes: M2, M2.5, M3 for frame assembly screws

tools_required.name: Phillips screwdriver set
tools_required.notes: PH1 and PH2 sizes

tools_required.name: Heat gun or lighter
tools_required.notes: For heat shrink tubing application

tools_required.name: Hobby knife / X-Acto knife
tools_required.notes: For trimming, cutting foam tape, stripping

tools_required.name: LiPo battery charger
tools_required.notes: Balance charger capable of 4S charging (e.g., ISDT, SkyRC). MANDATORY for safe LiPo use

tools_required.name: LiPo voltage checker
tools_required.notes: Cell checker/alarm that plugs into balance lead

tools_required.name: Zip ties (assorted sizes)
tools_required.notes: For cable management and securing wires to frame

tools_required.name: Double-sided tape / mounting tape
tools_required.notes: Included in kit, but extra may be useful

tools_required.name: Computer with USB
tools_required.notes: For firmware flashing, PID tuning, and ground control station software

tools_required.name: USB to Serial adapter (FTDI/CP2102)
tools_required.notes: For flashing STM32 and ESP32 if not using ST-Link

tools_required.name: ST-Link V2 programmer
tools_required.notes: For flashing STM32F405 firmware via SWD

tools_required.name: Propeller balancer
tools_required.notes: Magnetic or shaft-type balancer for vibration reduction

tools_required.name: Thread-locking compound (Loctite 243)
tools_required.notes: Medium-strength, for motor mount screws and critical frame bolts

tools_required.name: Electrical tape
tools_required.notes: For insulation and temporary wire securing

tools_required.name: Label maker or masking tape + marker
tools_required.notes: For labeling wires during assembly

tools_required.name: Safety glasses
tools_required.notes: Mandatory during soldering, cutting, and ALL flight tests

tools_required.name: Fire-resistant work mat
tools_required.notes: Silicone soldering mat recommended

tools_required.name: Caliper or ruler
tools_required.notes: For measuring wire lengths and verifying dimensions

materials_included: u-blox NEO-M8N GPS module with ceramic antenna
M3 nylon standoff and screw kit
safety_warnings: ⚠️ CRITICAL: LiPo batteries are EXTREMELY DANGEROUS if mishandled. They can catch fire, explode, or release toxic fumes. ALWAYS charge in a LiPo-safe fireproof bag on a non-flammable surface. NEVER leave charging unattended.
⚠️ CRITICAL: NEVER connect the battery while propellers are installed during bench testing. A spinning propeller can cause SEVERE lacerations, amputations, or death.
⚠️ CRITICAL: Always remove propellers before any firmware flashing, calibration, or configuration work at the bench.
⚠️ CRITICAL: Ensure the motor kill switch on your transmitter is functional and tested BEFORE every flight.

⚠️ CRITICAL: Comply with all local drone regulations. In the US, FAA Part 107 applies for commercial use; recreational flyers must follow FAA guidelines including registration, altitude limits (400ft AGL), visual line of sight, and airspace restrictions.
Wear safety glasses during all soldering, cutting, drilling, and flight testing activities.
Work in a well-ventilated area when soldering. Solder fumes are harmful—use a fume extractor if available.
Do not touch soldering iron tip or freshly soldered joints—severe burns can result.
LiPo battery: Never discharge below 3.3V per cell (13.2V total for 4S). Set low-voltage alarm to 14.0V (3.5V/cell) for landing warning.
LiPo battery: Never puncture, crush, short-circuit, or expose to temperatures above 60°C.
LiPo battery: Store at storage voltage (3.8V/cell, ~15.2V total) if not using for more than 3 days.
Carbon fiber dust is hazardous—wear a dust mask if you need to cut or drill the frame.
Always perform pre-flight checks: verify battery voltage, propeller tightness, control response, and GPS lock before takeoff.
First flights should be conducted in a large, open area away from people, animals, buildings, and power lines. Maintain at least 30 meters clearance.
Keep a fire extinguisher (Class D or ABC) accessible during battery charging and flight operations.
Disconnect the battery IMMEDIATELY if you notice any swelling, unusual heat, smoke, or strange odors.
This drone contains spinning parts at high RPM. Keep hands, hair, clothing, and loose objects away from propellers at all times.
Test all failsafe modes (signal loss RTH, low battery auto-land) at LOW altitude over soft ground before relying on them.
The ultrasonic obstacle avoidance is BASIC and directional only—it will NOT prevent all collisions. Fly with caution.
Do not fly in rain, snow, high winds (>20 mph), or near lightning. Electronics are not weatherproofed.

steps.title: Unpack and Inventory All Components
steps.description: Open all packages and carefully verify every component against the bill of materials. Lay everything out on a clean, well-lit workspace. This is critical—discovering a missing part mid-build is frustrating and delays the project. Take photos of everything for reference.
substeps: Clear a large workspace (at least 1m x 0.6m). Place a silicone mat or anti-static mat on the surface.
Open each package carefully—small components like resistors and capacitors are easy to lose.

Sort components into labeled groups: Frame, Motors/ESCs/Props, Power (battery, PDB, regulators, capacitors), Sensors (IMU, baro, compass, GPS, ultrasonics, ToF), Electronics (MCU, ESP32, receiver, SD module), Connectors/Wires, Hardware (standoffs, screws, tape), and Passive Components (resistors, capacitors, diodes, MOSFET).
Verify each component quantity against the BOM. Check ICs for correct part numbers printed on the chip.
Inspect the 450mm frame kit: count all plates, arms, screws, and landing gear pieces. Refer to the frame kit's own parts list.
Inspect the LiPo battery for any swelling, dents, or damage. Check that the XT60 connector and balance lead are intact. If damaged, DO NOT USE—dispose of properly.
Verify the FrSky Taranis QX7 transmitter has batteries or a charged battery pack. Confirm the X8R receiver is included.
Check that propellers are correct: 2 clockwise (CW, usually labeled 1045R) and 2 counter-clockwise (CCW, labeled 1045).
Place small components (resistors, capacitors, diodes) in labeled bags or compartments of a parts organizer.
tips: Photograph your complete parts layout—this serves as a reference and documentation.
Keep anti-static bags for ICs (STM32, ESP32) until you're ready to solder them.
Test your multimeter on a known battery to ensure it's working correctly.
Have the full BOM printed out and check off items as you verify them.
steps.image_hint: overhead photo of all drone components laid out on workbench organized by category

steps.title: Assemble the 450mm Quadcopter Frame
steps.description: Assemble the carbon fiber frame according to the manufacturer's instructions. The 450mm frame typically consists of a top plate, bottom plate, four arms, and landing gear. Take your time—the frame is the structural foundation of your drone.
substeps: Lay out all frame parts: top plate, bottom plate, 4 arms (may be integrated into plates), motor mounts, landing gear struts, and all screws/nuts.
If the frame uses separate arms: attach each arm to the bottom plate using the provided M3 screws. Tighten firmly but don't overtighten—carbon fiber can crack.
Apply a small drop of thread-locking compound (Loctite 243) to each frame screw before tightening. This prevents vibration-induced loosening during flight.
Attach the landing gear struts to the bottom plate at the designated mounting points. Ensure they are symmetrical.
DO NOT attach the top plate yet—you need access to the interior for mounting the PDB and wiring.
Verify the frame is square and symmetrical by measuring diagonal distances between opposite motor mounts. They should be equal (within 2mm).
Identify the FRONT of the frame. Mark it with tape or a marker. Convention: the front is between motors 1 and 2 in an 'X' configuration.
Label each arm position: Front-Right (Motor 1, CW), Front-Left (Motor 2, CCW), Rear-Left (Motor 3, CW), Rear-Right (Motor 4, CCW). Write these on tape on each arm.
tips: The standard motor numbering for ArduPilot/Betaflight X-configuration is: Front-Right=M1(CW), Front-Left=M2(CCW), Rear-Left=M3(CW), Rear-Right=M4(CCW). Verify this matches your firmware!
Don't fully tighten all screws on the first pass. Snug them lightly, verify alignment, then do a final tightening pass.
If any carbon fiber edges are sharp or rough, carefully sand them with fine-grit sandpaper (400+) while wearing a dust mask.
Keep all extra frame screws in a labeled bag—you'll need spares after crashes.
steps.image_hint: partially assembled 450mm carbon fiber quadcopter frame with arms attached to bottom plate, motor positions labeled

steps.title: Mount Motors to Frame Arms
steps.description: Attach the four 2212 920KV brushless motors to the motor mounts on each frame arm. Correct motor placement and secure mounting are essential for flight stability.
substeps: Identify the motor mounting holes on each arm tip. They typically accept M3 screws.
For each motor: align the motor's mounting holes with the arm's mounting holes. The motor shaft should point UPWARD.
Insert M3 screws (usually provided with the motors) through the motor base and into the arm mount holes from the top.
Apply thread-locking compound to each motor mounting screw—these experience extreme vibration.
Tighten all 4 screws per motor evenly in a cross pattern. The motor should be firmly seated with no wobble.
Route each motor's 3 power wires (usually unlabeled A/B/C) down along the arm toward the center of the frame. Leave enough slack for ESC connection.
Secure motor wires to the arm using small zip ties every 5-8cm to prevent wires from contacting propellers.
Repeat for all 4 motors. Verify all motors spin freely by hand with no grinding or resistance.
Label each motor's wires at the end with the motor position (M1-FR, M2-FL, M3-RL, M4-RR) using tape.
tips: Motor rotation direction is determined by ESC wiring (swapping any 2 of the 3 motor wires reverses direction). Don't worry about direction yet.
If motor screws are too long and bottom out (hit the windings inside), use washers or shorter screws.
Spin each motor by hand and listen—any scraping sound indicates debris or a defective bearing. Replace before proceeding.
Keep the motor bell (rotating part) free from metal filings—the magnets attract them.
steps.image_hint: close-up of brushless motor being mounted to carbon fiber arm with M3 screws, wires routed along arm

steps.title: Prepare and Mount the Power Distribution Board (PDB)
steps.description: The Matek PDB is the central power hub that distributes battery power to all 4 ESCs and provides regulated 5V and 12V outputs for avionics. Prepare it with filtering capacitors and mount it to the frame's center.
substeps: Inspect the Matek PDB. Identify: battery input pads (large, usually center), 4 ESC output pad pairs (large, at corners/edges), 5V BEC output, 12V BEC output, and ground pads.

Solder a 470uF 25V electrolytic capacitor across the main battery input pads (+ to +, - to -). This filters voltage spikes from ESCs. OBSERVE POLARITY—the stripe/negative side goes to the negative pad.
Solder the remaining three 470uF 25V capacitors: one near each pair of ESC output pads if space allows, or distribute them evenly around the PDB periphery across power/ground.

Solder the XT60 female connector to the battery input pads of the PDB using 14AWG wire. Red to positive, black to negative. Keep wires as short as practical (5-8cm). Use generous solder for these high-current joints.
Apply heat shrink tubing over each XT60 solder joint for insulation and strain relief.

Solder an SS34 Schottky diode in series with the positive battery input for reverse polarity protection. Cathode band faces TOWARD the PDB (current flows from battery to PDB). Note: This diode will handle up to 3A; for full system current, you may instead wire it to protect only the avionics 5V rail—see Step 8.

ALTERNATIVE for reverse polarity on high-current path: Skip the series diode here (it cannot handle motor currents of 60A+). Instead, use the SS34 diodes only on the 5V/3.3V avionics supply in later steps. Wire the XT60 directly to PDB.
Mount the PDB to the center of the bottom frame plate using M3 nylon standoffs (4 corners). Use 6-8mm standoffs to provide clearance above the frame plate.

Verify no solder joints on the PDB bottom can short against the carbon fiber frame (which is conductive!). Add electrical tape or Kapton tape between PDB bottom and frame if standoff height is minimal.
Test with multimeter: Check continuity between + and - pads (should be OPEN/no continuity). Check each ESC output pad pair for correct connection to battery input.
tips: Carbon fiber is electrically conductive! Always use nylon standoffs and verify insulation between any PCB and the frame.
For the XT60 connector, tin both the wire and the connector cup before joining them. Use plenty of solder and heat—cold joints on power connections can cause in-flight failures.
The 470uF capacitors are critical for suppressing voltage spikes from ESC switching. Don't skip them.
Pre-tin all PDB pads before attaching wires—it makes soldering much easier.
steps.image_hint: Matek PDB mounted on nylon standoffs on frame bottom plate, with XT60 connector soldered and capacitors visible

notes: Parts sourced from robu.in (INR converted at $1 = ₹83.3)
